commit_message:
Remove old network_data examples

These old example files no longer work with TripleO. Thus, this
change is removing them to avoid confusion for our users. We can
instead rely on the files here:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/tree/1a1fb27275c7e66f6c9d7f9b154789782dde23b6/network-data-samples

Change-Id: I46ed94253802b8f748a320e609fa7244be51ed59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/43/856343/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # List of networks, used for j2 templating of routed networks # # Supported values: # # name: Name of the network (mandatory) # name_lower: lowercase version of name used for filenames # (optional, defaults to name.lower()) # service_net_map_replace: if name_lower is set to a custom name this should be set # to original default (optional). This field is only necessary when # changing the default network names, not when adding a new custom network. # enabled: Is the network enabled (optional, defaults to true) # NOTE: False will use noop.yaml for unused legacy networks to support upgrades. # vlan: vlan for the network (optional) # vip: Enable creation of a virtual IP on this network. Only for networks attached # to the roles running high-availability clustering (Controller by default). # ip_subnet: IP/CIDR, e.g. '192.168.24.0/24' or '2001:db8:fd00:1000::/64' # (optional, may use parameter defaults instead) # allocation_pools: IP range list e.g. [{'start':'10.0.0.4', 'end':'10.0.0.250'}] # gateway_ip: gateway for the network (optional, may use parameter defaults) # routes: Optional, list of networks that should be routed via network gateway. # Example: [{'destination':'10.0.0.0/16', 'nexthop':'10.0.0.1'}] # A single /16 supernet route could be used for 255 smaller /24 subnets. # ipv6_subnet: Optional, sets default IPv6 subnet if IPv4 is already defined. # ipv6_allocation_pools: Set default IPv6 allocation pools if IPv4 allocation pools # are already defined. # ipv6_gateway: Set an IPv6 gateway if IPv4 gateway already defined. # routes_ipv6: Optional, list of networks that should be routed via network gateway. # Example: [{'destination':'fd00:fd00:fd00:3004::/64', # 'nexthop':'fd00:fd00:fd00:3000::1'}] # ipv6: If ip_subnet not defined, this specifies that the network is IPv6-only. # NOTE: IP-related values set parameter defaults in templates, may be overridden, # either by operators, or e.g in environments/network-isolation-v6.yaml where we # set some default IPv6 addresses. # compat_name: for existing stack you may need to override the default # transformation for the resource's name. # subnets: A map of additional subnets for the network (optional). The map # takes the following format: # {'<subnet name>': {'enabled': '<true|false>', # 'vlan': '<vlan-id>', # 'ip_subnet': '<IP/CIDR>', # 'allocation_pools': '<IP range list>', # 'gateway_ip': '<gateway IP>', # 'routes': '<Routes list>', # 'ipv6_subnet': '<IPv6/CIDR>', # 'ipv6_allocation_pools': '<IPv6 range list>', # 'gateway_ipv6': '<IPv6 gateway>', # 'routes_ipv6': '<Routes list>'}} # # Example: # - name Example # vip: false # ip_subnet: '10.0.2.0/24' # allocation_pools: [{'start': '10.0.2.4', 'end': '10.0.2.250'}] # gateway_ip: '10.0.2.254' # subnets: # example_siteB_rack1: # vlan: 11 # ip_subnet: '172.16.1.64/26' # allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.1.70', 'end': '172.16.1.110'}] # gateway_ip: '172.16.1.65' # # To support backward compatibility, two versions of the network definitions will # be created, network/<network>.yaml and network/<network>_v6.yaml. Only # one of these files may be used in the deployment at a time, since the # parameters used for configuration are the same in both files. In the # future, this behavior may be changed to create only one file for custom # networks. You may specify IPv6 addresses for ip_subnet, allocation_pools, # and gateway_ip if no IPv4 addresses are used for a custom network, or set # ipv6: true, and the network/<network>.yaml file will be configured as IPv6. # # For configuring both IPv4 and IPv6 on the same interface, use two separate # networks, and then assign both IPs to the same interface in a custom NIC # configuration templates. # # The ordering of the networks below will determine the order in which NICs # are assigned in the network/config/multiple-nics templates, beginning with # NIC2, Control Plane is always NIC1. - commit_message:
Clarify the client code is not python bindings

This patch adds notes clarifying that users should use openstacksdk
for Octavia python bindings and not the client code.
It also corrects the README URL to the docs to point to the client
documentation instead of the main Octavia docs.

Change-Id: I877e08085813b436ff7149604e6a9f6b271fe6f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-octaviaclient refs/changes/68/826768/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Documentation: https://docs.openstack.org/python-octaviaclient/latest/.. note:: This project is only intended to be used for the OpenStack Client CLI. The `openstacksdk <https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk>`_ should be used for python bindings.

commit_message:
Neutron: Deprecate unmaintained features

This change deprecates the following features related to Neutron,
because these have been unmaintained and still requires host services
instead of containers.

 - linuxbridge mechanism driver
 - networking-l2gw
 - netwokring-bgpvpn + bagpipe

Change-Id: Id6356cbb2162c0985851f27fbb3039be36fea84a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/49/846249/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OS::TripleO::Services::NeutronBgpVpnApi: ../deployment/deprecated/neutron/neutron-bgpvpn-api-container-puppet.yaml

subject: Cleanup fanout queues on ovs agent stop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-09-05 06:40:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/382f00e844aeaef3b2a13619f810b90bb885d562', 'message': 'Cleanup fanout queues on ovs agent stop

Previously when a neutron-openvswitch-agent was stopped it left
behind the following fanout queues in rabbitmq:
neutron-vo-Network-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Port-1.1_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroup-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroupRule-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SubPort-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Subnet-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Trunk-1.1_fanout_someuuid

In this change we ensure that all but the SubPort and Trunk fanout
queues are correctly removed from rabbitmq by cleanly stopping the
RemoteResourceCache when the agent stops.

Partial-Bug: #1586731
Change-Id: I672f9414a1a8ed91e259e9379ca707a70f6b4467
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-09-05 09:50:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/63401c72db0572ea9deef22410c2af745b2ce1a0', 'message': 'Cleanup fanout queues on ovs agent stop

Previously when a neutron-openvswitch-agent was stopped it left
behind the following fanout queues in rabbitmq:
neutron-vo-Network-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Port-1.1_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroup-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroupRule-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SubPort-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Subnet-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Trunk-1.1_fanout_someuuid

In this change we ensure that all but the SubPort and Trunk fanout
queues are correctly removed from rabbitmq by cleanly stopping the
RemoteResourceCache when the agent stops.

commit_message:
Cleanup fanout queues on ovs agent stop

Previously when a neutron-openvswitch-agent was stopped it left
behind the following fanout queues in rabbitmq:
neutron-vo-Network-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Port-1.1_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroup-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SecurityGroupRule-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-SubPort-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Subnet-1.0_fanout_someuuid
neutron-vo-Trunk-1.1_fanout_someuuid

In this change we ensure that all but the SubPort and Trunk fanout
queues are correctly removed from rabbitmq by cleanly stopping the
RemoteResourceCache when the agent stops.

Partial-Bug: #1586731
Change-Id: I672f9414a1a8ed91e259e9379ca707a70f6b4467

commit_message:
Support vimConnectionInfo.extra when CNF deploy

If 'vimConnectionInfo.extra' is included in the Input
parameter file specified during CNF instantiation via helm,
this information is taken in and used as a parameter
for deployment via helm.
If the extra parameter is set in the config-file specified
when the 'openstack vim register' command is executed,
the information is saved in the VIM DB.

Implements: blueprint remove-cnf-restriction
Change-Id: I11f83857f784eea1f8c4caefdc6161a86fefe4e4

subject: Don't assume /etc/hosts exists
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-09-12 08:57:26.000000000', 'files': ['roles/baremetal/tasks/pre-install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collection-kolla/commit/69a1460b68577b7100997cd5819bccfb1da06a6f', 'message': 'Don't assume /etc/hosts exists

The baremetal role adds entries to /etc/hosts. If the file does not
exist, it will fail:

  TASK [baremetal : Ensure localhost in /etc/hosts] ****************************************
  fatal: [compute2]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "Destination /etc/hosts does not exist !", "rc": 257}

Though surprising, this is possible, and we should not assume that
/etc/hosts exists.

This change modifies the above task to create the file if it does not
exist.

Closes-Bug: #1982837
Change-Id: Ic419ee13a10b3fa1b890cfec23bab0a67489eb96
(cherry picked from commit 25020e469f4a6f913ebaf21a3dc812d1fcbfa53a)
'}]
commit_message:
Don't assume /etc/hosts exists

The baremetal role adds entries to /etc/hosts. If the file does not
exist, it will fail:

  TASK [baremetal : Ensure localhost in /etc/hosts] ****************************************
  fatal: [compute2]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "Destination /etc/hosts does not exist !", "rc": 257}

Though surprising, this is possible, and we should not assume that
/etc/hosts exists.

This change modifies the above task to create the file if it does not
exist.

Closes-Bug: #1982837
Change-Id: Ic419ee13a10b3fa1b890cfec23bab0a67489eb96
(cherry picked from commit 25020e469f4a6f913ebaf21a3dc812d1fcbfa53a)

commit_message:
Added tox environment for gathering coverage

This technique was borrowed from the tox "cover" environment in
openstack/nova's tox.ini.  This leverages the fact that stestr lets
you override the python executable via the PYTHON environment
variable.  Doing this allows us to easily generate coverage for our
unit tests.

An important caveat is that this does not provide any coverage for
tests via zaza, amulet, etc.  It is purely focused on the unit tests.

Note that this replaces the previous .coveragerc; coverage
configuration is instead pulled from tox.ini.

Change-Id: Ica8e46b21c3373151a6e0d6144b06f5426fb3511

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python3 # -*- coding: us-ascii -*- """Check for issues with NVME hardware devices.""" import argparse import re import subprocess import sys from nagios_plugin3 import CriticalError, UnknownError, try_check def parse_ovs_status(): """Check for known errors in ovs-vsctl output.""" try: cmd = ["/usr/bin/ovs-vsctl", "show"] ovs_output = subprocess.check_output(cmd, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT) except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e: raise UnknownError("UNKNOWN: Failed to query ovs: {}".format(e)) ovs_vsctl_show_errors = [] ovs_error_re = re.compile(r"^.*error: (?P<message>.+)$", re.I) for line in ovs_output.decode(errors="ignore").splitlines(): m = ovs_error_re.match(line) if m: ovs_vsctl_show_errors.append(m.group("message")) if ovs_vsctl_show_errors: numerrs = len(ovs_vsctl_show_errors) raise CriticalError( "CRITICAL: Found {} error(s) in ovs-vsctl show: " "{}".format(numerrs, ", ".join(ovs_vsctl_show_errors)) ) print("OK: no errors found in openvswitch") def parse_args(argv=None): """Process CLI arguments.""" parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( prog="check_openvswitch", description=( "this program checks openvswitch status and outputs an " "appropriate Nagios status line" ), formatter_class=argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter, ) return parser.parse_args(argv) def main(argv): """Define main subroutine.""" parse_args(argv) try_check(parse_ovs_status) if __name__ == "__main__": main(sys.argv[1:])

commit_message:
Added tox environment for gathering coverage

This technique was borrowed from the tox "cover" environment in
openstack/nova's tox.ini.  This leverages the fact that stestr lets
you override the python executable via the PYTHON environment
variable.  Doing this allows us to easily generate coverage for our
unit tests.

An important caveat is that this does not provide any coverage for
tests via zaza, amulet, etc.  It is purely focused on the unit tests.

Note that this replaces the previous .coveragerc; coverage
configuration is instead pulled from tox.ini.

Change-Id: I91983cad9365910c549ba79909b244bf539a47b6

commit_message:
Expose the haproxy-template option

This commit adds a haproxy-template config option which maps onto the
haproxy_template octavia option[0].
The template is to be specified as a base64 encoded string, which will
be decoded and written in /etc/octavia/haproxy-custom.cfg.j2

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/ocata/main/configref.html#haproxy_amphora.haproxy_template option

Change-Id: Ie2249f201abe2dd7adcf27e9b94deb8c0979d515
Closes-Bug: #1859025
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-octavia refs/changes/28/701728/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% if options.haproxy_template -%} haproxy_template = {{ options.custom_haproxy_template }} {% endif -%}

commit_message:
Add support for HAProxy L7 checks

This change add several configuration options to enable HTTP checks
to the HAProxy configuration, instead of the default TCP connection
checks (which continue to be the default).

Change-Id: I8b16ddab3961b4637798f5328a306b70983559fd
Closes-Bug: #1880610
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-glance refs/changes/24/750224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: haproxy-check-http: type: boolean default: False description: | If True uses HTTP (Layer 7) checks for backends in haproxy, used in HA configurations. If False uses a TCP check (default) haproxy-check-http-request: type: string default: OPTIONS / HTTP/1.0 description: | If HAProxy HTTP checks are enabled, this configures the request used for the check. Refer to the HAProxy documentation for the syntax details. haproxy-check-http-expected: type: string default: expect status 200 description: | If HAProxy HTTP checks are enabled, this configures the expected response from the backend. Refer to the HAProxy documentation for the syntax details.

commit_message:
Clarify placement guidelines regarding OSD

This change also updates the test's unit tests
to the new Yoga versions, dropping python3.5
from the unit tests.

Closes-Bug: #1681746

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/19/815119/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: addition of storage devices. Ideally the ceph-mon charm would be deployed on a minimal but dedicated node as per the Ceph [recommendations](http://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/start/hardware-recommendations/#minimum-hardware-recommendations). The recommended topology is a LXD container on machines that are hosting the OSD units. In deployments where LXD isn't well supported, dedicated virtual machines are recommended.

commit_message:
Add force flag to openstack-upgrade action

This flag will allow upgrading to new package versions regardless of
whether there is a new release of OpenStack available. This can be
useful to dist-upgrade to a proposed pocket or PPA for testing, or
to for upgrade all packages to new stable versions.

Change-Id: I3f74b77eb930674a61874c68f5cb66fb1ae7caac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-neutron-api refs/changes/12/815012/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: params: force: type: boolean default: false description: | Force the upgrade regardless of whether a new OpenStack release is available.

commit_message:
Updating the process_list_path config variable

Previously, the process_list_path was pointing to the
wrong and non-existent directory on the filesystem,
causing process-monitor to behave in a wrong way. This
patch is to point the process-monitor to a right config.

Closes-Bug: #1941623
Change-Id: I8126fc9cf946088bcdb33cf2716f1bedd2671646
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-masakari-monitors refs/changes/28/806028/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: process_list_path = /etc/masakarimonitors/process_list.yaml

After the shutdown of a RabbitMQ cluster, the individual units have to
be booted in reverse order or MNesia will block. This can lead to hook

- Add `start` hook to test the correct startup order
- Inform user in case a unit is blocked on another unit

Change-Id: I6520dc0f2e0fea55b292d0db2831547c584ee851
Co-Authored-By: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2020-06-03 16:29:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server/commit/c1efe4dad47367c28b01432b0b33fc131a677f70', 'message': "Be smarter about RabbitMQ cluster unit startup

After the shutdown of a RabbitMQ cluster, the individual units have to
be booted in reverse order or MNesia will block [1]. This can lead to
hook failures which are hard to recover from.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a RabbitMQ HA deployment with units rabbitmq-server/{0,1,2}
2. Shutdown rabbitmq-server units in order [0, 1, 2]
3. Boot rabbitmq-server/0

The `update-status` hook on rabbitmq-server/0 will fail because the
rabbitmq-server.service can not start without the other two units.

Steps to mitigate:

The Mnesia database maintains the online status of the other brokers
in the RabbitMQ cluster [1]. We can query that status on charm `start`
and inform the operator that other units need to be booted also.

This change introduces an Erlang script which queries the Mnesia
database for the online status of the cluster units. The change also
introduces a `start` hook which uses the information gathered from the
Erlang script to determine whether the other rabbitmq-server units
that are necessary for startup are available. If they aren't the
status is updated appropriately to indicate to the operator which
other units need to be started up.

[1] https://erlang.org/doc/apps/mnesia/Mnesia_chap7.html#loading-tables-at-startup

Change-Id: I6520dc0f2e0fea55b292d0db2831547c584ee851
Closes-Bug: #1828988
Co-Authored-By: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
"}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2020-06-03 17:16:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server/commit/a2cf0bb1ea99c83ce434d40c467d107412abdca0', 'message': "Be smarter about RabbitMQ cluster unit startup

After the shutdown of a RabbitMQ cluster, the individual units have to
be booted in reverse order or MNesia will block [1]. This can lead to
hook failures which are hard to recover from.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a RabbitMQ HA deployment with units rabbitmq-server/{0,1,2}
2. Shutdown rabbitmq-server units in order [0, 1, 2]
3. Boot rabbitmq-server/0

The `update-status` hook on rabbitmq-server/0 will fail because the
rabbitmq-server.service can not start without the other two units.

Steps to mitigate:

The Mnesia database maintains the online status of the other brokers
in the RabbitMQ cluster [1]. We can query that status on charm `start`
and inform the operator that other units need to be booted also.

This change introduces an Erlang script which queries the Mnesia
database for the online status of the cluster units. The change also
introduces a `start` hook which uses the information gathered from the
Erlang script to determine whether the other rabbitmq-server units
that are necessary for startup are available. If they aren't the
status is updated appropriately to indicate to the operator which
other units need to be started up.

[1] https://erlang.org/doc/apps/mnesia/Mnesia_chap7.html#loading-tables-at-startup

Change-Id: I6520dc0f2e0fea55b292d0db2831547c584ee851
Closes-Bug: #1828988
Co-Authored-By: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Be smarter about RabbitMQ cluster unit startup

After the shutdown of a RabbitMQ cluster, the individual units have to
be booted in reverse order or MNesia will block [1]. This can lead to
hook failures which are hard to recover from.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a RabbitMQ HA deployment with units rabbitmq-server/{0,1,2}
2. Shutdown rabbitmq-server units in order [0, 1, 2]
3. Boot rabbitmq-server/0

The `update-status` hook on rabbitmq-server/0 will fail because the
rabbitmq-server.service can not start without the other two units.

Steps to mitigate:

The Mnesia database maintains the online status of the other brokers
in the RabbitMQ cluster [1]. We can query that status on charm `start`
and inform the operator that other units need to be booted also.

This change introduces an Erlang script which queries the Mnesia
database for the online status of the cluster units. The change also
introduces a `start` hook which uses the information gathered from the
Erlang script to determine whether the other rabbitmq-server units
that are necessary for startup are available. If they aren't the
status is updated appropriately to indicate to the operator which
other units need to be started up.

[1] https://erlang.org/doc/apps/mnesia/Mnesia_chap7.html#loading-tables-at-startup

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/323

Change-Id: I6520dc0f2e0fea55b292d0db2831547c584ee851
Closes-Bug: #1828988
Co-Authored-By: Jorge Niedbalski <jorge.niedbalski@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server refs/changes/52/732452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_startup_status(): """Query the Mnesia database and find nodes marked as `mnesia_down`. The function returns a dictionary which contains the cluster nodes and their status. """ cmd = ['escript', 'files/clusterpeers.erl', '/var/lib/rabbitmq/mnesia/rabbit@' + get_unit_hostname()] nodes = {} try: output = subprocess.check_output(cmd, env={"HOME": "/var/tmp"}) output = list(map(str.strip, output.decode('utf-8').split('\n'))) all_nodes = set(map(str.strip, list( filter(lambda x: re.match("^All:", x) is not None, output))[0].split(' '))) - {'All:'} down_nodes = set(map(str.strip, list( filter(lambda x: re.match("^Down:", x) is not None, output))[0].split(' '))) for node in all_nodes: if node in down_nodes: nodes[node] = False else: nodes[node] = True except Exception as ex: log(str(ex), level='DEBUG') finally: return nodes def stop_app(): ''' Stop the rabbitmq app ''' status_set('maintenance', 'Stopping rabbitmq application') rabbitmqctl('stop_app') stop_app() stop_app()

subject: Exclude erasure coded pools from eligible pools
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-04-03 16:56:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-rbd-mirror/commit/078bcd7b66e03764d8af718a8a68abe18936ecce', 'message': 'Exclude erasure coded pools from eligible pools

Filter erasure coded pools from the list of eligible pools since
Ceph does not support mirroring these pools. Since Ceph does not
provide a simple way when querying the pools to see if they are
acting as a metadata pool for an erasure coded RBD pool, the
metadata pools are automatically excluded by naming convention.

For those scenarios where the metadata pool does not follow the
naming convention (<pool>-metadata), a new config option is added
to exclude-pools from enabling for replication.

Zaza bundle updates are to include an EC pool to validate that
erasure coded pools are properly excluded.

Closes-Bug: #1898504
Change-Id: I083e2dce9b1205b9b0812b3dbc9fe6ea2e29c012
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2021-04-04 03:42:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-rbd-mirror/commit/34dfcb7038c8ef6124a2ceb1346c702de2cf15aa', 'message': 'Exclude erasure coded pools from eligible pools

Filter erasure coded pools from the list of eligible pools since
Ceph does not support mirroring these pools. Since Ceph does not
provide a simple way when querying the pools to see if they are
acting as a metadata pool for an erasure coded RBD pool, the
metadata pools are automatically excluded by naming convention.

For those scenarios where the metadata pool does not follow the
naming convention (<pool>-metadata), a new config option is added
to exclude-pools from enabling for replication.

Zaza bundle updates are to include an EC pool to validate that
erasure coded pools are properly excluded.

Closes-Bug: #1898504
Change-Id: I083e2dce9b1205b9b0812b3dbc9fe6ea2e29c012
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2021-04-04 03:44:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-rbd-mirror/commit/b41b3fb892b88043d5dcb0fccde8cdeae7d9222c', 'message': "Exclude erasure coded pools from eligible pools

Filter erasure coded pools from the list of eligible pools since
Ceph does not support mirroring these pools. Since Ceph does not
provide a simple way when querying the pools to see if they are
acting as a metadata pool for an erasure coded RBD pool, the
CephBroker requests are updated to accept 'none' as an
rbd_mirroring_mode. When the rbd_mirroring_mode is set to 'none'
this charm will not setup mirroring for hte pool.

For those scenarios where the pool is created by hand, a new config
option is added to exclude-pools from enabling for replication.

Zaza bundle updates are to include an EC pool to validate that
erasure coded pools are properly excluded.

Closes-Bug: #1898504

commit_message:
Exclude erasure coded pools from eligible pools

Filter erasure coded pools from the list of eligible pools since
Ceph does not support mirroring these pools. Since Ceph does not
provide a simple way when querying the pools to see if they are
acting as a metadata pool for an erasure coded RBD pool, the
CephBroker requests are updated to accept 'none' as an
rbd_mirroring_mode. When the rbd_mirroring_mode is set to 'none'
this charm will not setup mirroring for the pool.

For those scenarios where the pool is created by hand, a new config
option is added to exclude-pools from enabling for replication.

Updates are needed to the mirror_pool_status function as the rbd
commandline client will error out with EINVAL if the mirror pool status
is called for a pool which does not have replication enabled.

Zaza bundle updates are to include an EC pool to validate that
erasure coded pools are properly excluded.

Closes-Bug: #1898504
Change-Id: I083e2dce9b1205b9b0812b3dbc9fe6ea2e29c012

commit_message:
[WIP] Generate wheelhouse at build-time from OpenStack requirements

The charms high level direct dependencies are kept in
src/wheelhouse.txt.in.

A new `generate-wheelhouse-txt` tox target is used to expand the
high level list into a explicit list of dependencies built with
constraints from the upstream OpenStack requirements repository.

The new target is called from the `build` target, so that the
build process for the charm will be no different from other
charms.

Change-Id: Ida8e23630b177da28d3e1a3217f9eab5c0190d80

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of mock

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we can use the
standard lib unittest.mock module instead.

Change-Id: I7b7fc379f97853c02f99aafe9abedf68ad942534

commit_message:
Add the specification for disk-replacement

This patchset adds the specs for disk replacement operations in
the ceph-osd charm, including the additions needed for the
'add-disk' action, as well as the new 'remove-disk' action.

Change-Id: I11ba6e21b3b2fd91b6dfd7c64aabcecb1b5be32b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-specs refs/changes/23/821623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2021 Canonical This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: "None". For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ========================== Disk replacement additions ========================== The Ceph OSD charm should provide better tools to handle disk replacement. Rationale ========= As it stands right now, there is no simple way to replace an existing disk with a new device. An operator can opt to bring up a new OSD configured to use the new device and then remove the OSD that was using the old one, but this can be a rather error-prone way of doing things. Instead, we propose a new way of performing the replacement: - Enhance the ‘add-disk’ action to support more parameters so that it’s capable of setting up a disk in the same way that other disks are being used. - Create a 'remove-osd' action that will include details on re-adding a disk (with 'add-disk') in its output. Specification ============= Replacing a disk is not a simple operation. The disk that we are replacing can be fulfilling multiple roles at the same time (for instance, it can be acting as backing for ‘bcache’ or similar technologies, or it can be part of an LVM volume that was created by Ceph specifically). As such, it is important that the new device be configured to act as closely as possible as the old disk was, matching the user’s expectations to the greatest possible extent. Removing an OSD --------------- Operators currently have no way to cleanly remove an OSD from Ceph using the charms alone. Instead, operators who wish to remove a disk must revert to logging into the node itself and performing a variety of steps_ which can be error-prone. To simplify this for an operator, a new action will be implemented that will allow operators to safely remove an OSD from Ceph. Removing an OSD from a Ceph cluster involves the following procedure_: 1. Marking the OSD as ‘out’. This action causes the ceph cluster to start rebalancing data away from the OSD. 2. Validate that the OSD is safe to destroy. 3. Stopping the OSD process (this will cause the OSD to go out + down). 4. Destroy/Purge the OSD from the ceph cluster. 5. Remove cache sets. Removing an OSD from a cluster is not always a safe action to perform, and if done incorrectly will lead to loss of access to data and/or data loss. The `remove-osd` action will perform various sanity checks along the way and fail with appropriate error messages if it is determined that it is unsafe to continue. The action will first prepare the OSD to be removed by marking the OSD as out. This tells the Ceph cluster that the OSD should not receive any new data and data will begin to migrate away as PGs will be remapped. Draining the OSD will take some time depending on the cluster, and the next step should not proceed until the OSD is safe to destroy. The amount of time it takes for any given OSD to reach a state where it is safe to destroy is dependent upon several factors including the state of the cluster, bandwidth, and the amount of data needed to backfill to other OSDs within the cluster. As such, a timeout will be used to limit the duration to wait for the OSD to be safe in order to allow other charm hooks to be executed. If the OSD does not reach a state where it is safe to remove during this timeout period, the action will fail with a message to the user indicating that the OSD is not currently safe to remove and that the action should be retried when the cluster has settled down. The OSD will be left marked as out to allow the cluster to continue to drain the OSD without placing new data on the OSD. When the OSD is safe to destroy, the OSD service will be stopped. Once safely stopped, the OSD will either be purged or destroyed, depending on whether the user has requested to purge the OSD or not. When removing the OSD from ceph, both the purge and destroy options will remove the OSD from Ceph, however the destroy action will preserve the OSD ID for reuse while the purge action will wipe all information, including the ID. After the OSD is removed from the Ceph cluster, if the underlying disk being used for Ceph is using a cache set, the backing device will be removed from the cache set. If the backing device is the last device in the cache set, the backing device will be detached and the cache device will be wiped. If the devices being removed are recognized as being backing a bcache scheme, then the associated bcache device will be removed from the system, regardless of whether such device was created by the charm or not. The remove-osd action will have the following parameters available that determine various behaviors of the action: .. code-block:: yaml parameters: osd-devices: type: string default: description: | A space delimited list of disks to remove. Valid entries for each device specified are paths to devices. Note, this parameter is mutually exclusive with the osd-ids parameter. osd-ids: type: string default: description: | A space delimited list of osd ids whose disks should be entries for each osd will be [osd].<id>. Note, this parameter is mutually exclusive with the osd-devices parameter. timeout: type: integer default: 5 description: | The duration (in minutes) to wait for OSDs to reach a state where it is safe to destroy the OSD. Value specified must be greater than 0. purge: type: boolean default: false description: | Determines whether or not the OSD will be fully purged from the Ceph cluster or if the OSD ID will be available for reuse. force: type: boolean default: false description: | Determines whether or not to forcefully remove the OSD from the Ceph cluster, even when it is not determined to be safe to destroy the OSD. The action will still wait the specified amount of time to allow the OSD to become safe, but will proceed with destroying the OSD if it is not safe. format: type: enum values: text, json default: text description: Determines the output format returned for the command. Adding an OSD ------------- The existing action will need to be enhanced in order to support the workflow needed for replacing disks. To recap, the `add-disk` action involves the following: - Perform various checks on the passed devices to see that they are clean, unmounted, etc. - Create the necessary volumes and groups (Varies depending on the Ceph version) plus the mount points. This effectively incorporates the device into the cluster. - Tune the device to maximize the throughput. - Inform the monitors of the changes so that their OSD count is accurate. The added features for this action involve the incorporation of the bcache technology. By specifying a caching device, the action will create a bcache kernel name, which will end up being the effective disk used as specified above. Furthermore, the user will have the option to set a partition size, which will indicate the maximum size used from the caching device to accelerate access to the backing one. Note that these extra features add another point of failure - The creation of the bcache, to be more precise. Nonetheless, the implementation will revert any devices created on its behalf and leave the state of the local node as it was, previous to the invocation of the action. That is to say, if a bcache device is created and an error occurs before the action runs to the completion, said device will be removed from the system transparently. The available parameters that can be used for the add-disk action will thus be: .. code-block:: yaml parameters: osd-devices: type: string default: description: | A space-delimited list of disks to format and setup as OSD volumes. osd-ids: type: string default: description: | A space-delimited list of osd-id’s to be reactivated. Typically, these would be IDs that were previously removed (but not purged) by the remove-osd command. bucket: type: string default: description: The name of the bucket in Ceph to add the devices into. cache-devices: type: string default: description: | A space-delimited list of devices that will serve as caching for the newly created bcache devices. If more than one device is passed, then they will be used in a round-robin fashion among the backing devices. Ideally, these should point to high speed (i.e: Flash, NVM, etc) kind of devices, but the action will make no such checks. partition-size: type: integer default: 0 description: | If nonzero, and the cache-device option was specified, the action will partition the caching device into N sub-devices (N being the number of devices specified in the option osd-devices), sized to this parameter (in GB). As such, each passed device will be cached by a separate partition. Replacing an OSD ---------------- There are a few concerns to consider when it comes to replacing an OSD. Logically, replacing an OSD is simply a remove-osd action followed by an add-disk action. However, there are some subtle differences in the behavior expected when replacing versus expanding. Operators may become accustomed to certain OSD IDs being on certain hosts and preserving the OSD IDs allows those IDs to be reused when a new OSD is added. To facilitate this scenario, the OSD ID will be preserved for future use by default when the remove-osd action is run and the add-disk action will accept an osd-id parameter that allows the operator to select the OSD ID. Some deployments will use caching devices to improve performance to the underlying disk, however it may not be clear to the user what the caching device configuration of a disk was prior to it being removed. To assist users, the remove-osd action will provide information to the user regarding which parameters to specify when adding a new OSD using the add-osd action. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Luciano Lo Giudice Work Items ---------- - Enhance the 'add-disk' action. - Implement the 'remove-disk' action. Gerrit Topic ------------ Use the 'add-disk' and 'remove-disk' gerrit topics for all patches related to this spec. Repositories ------------ No new repositories need to be created. Documentation ------------- The documentation for the ceph-osd charm will need to be updated to reflect the changes. Security -------- No apparent security risks. Testing ------- Functional tests will need to be added to try out the complete flow of adding a new disk, removing it and then re-adding it with the previous OSD id, thus verifying that the OSD could be replaced. In addition, Unit tests will be added to cover the new functionality. Dependencies ============ None. .. _steps: https://ubuntu.com/ceph/docs/replacing-osd-disks .. _procedure: https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rados/operations/add-or-rm-osds/

commit_message:
Fix misc issues with instances-path usage

Fix use of ephemeral-device with instances-path to ensure that
the configured block device is mounted in the desired location.

Ensure instances-path directory actually exists.

Change-Id: I81725f602ba3086bc142d59104e4bfc80918d8cf

commit_message:
Implemented deferred service restart Nagios check

* New check alerts on CRITICAL when deferred restarts are detected
* New check is found at files/check_rabbitmq_deferred_restarts.py
* New check only runs when `enable-auto-restarts` is False
    * Check is removed when `enable-auto-restarts` returns to True
* Only alerts for deferred service restarts - not deferred hooks
* Implemented similarly to other nagios checks
* New logic required in hooks/rabbitmq_server_relations.py:
    * The `if not allowed` check in `config_changed` function now syncs
    nrpe files and renders the new check

Change-Id: Ie5f339846a5576f502ce743d48571297dd00c7c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-rabbitmq-server refs/changes/29/816729/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not config('enable-auto-restarts'): rsync(os.path.join(charm_dir(), 'files', 'check_rabbitmq_deferred_restarts.py'), os.path.join(NAGIOS_PLUGINS, 'check_rabbitmq_deferred_restarts.py')) if config('enable-auto-restarts'): # This script is redundant if the value `enable-auto-restarts` isn't # in the config remove_file(os.path.join(NAGIOS_PLUGINS, 'check_rabbitmq_deferred_restarts.py')) def nrpe_update_deferred_restarts_check(nrpe_compat): """Add/Remove the RabbitMQ deferred service check If the enable-auto-restarts is set to `False`, it will add the deferred restarts check, otherwise it will remove it. :param nrpe_compat: the NRPE class object :type: nrpe.NRPE """ shortname = RABBIT_USER + '_deferred_restarts' cmd = '{}/check_rabbitmq_deferred_restarts.py'.format(NAGIOS_PLUGINS) if not config('enable-auto-restarts'): log('Adding rabbitmq deferred restart check', level=INFO) nrpe_compat.add_check( shortname=shortname, description='Check for deferred service restarts', check_cmd=cmd) else: log('Removing rabbitmq deferred restart check', level=INFO) nrpe_compat.remove_check( shortname=shortname, description='Remove deferred service restarts check', check_cmd=cmd)

commit_message:
debug: Add loop counter for identity_changed hook.

Add counter and a total count of relations that will run
identity_changed hook. Rationale for this is that running a
identity_changed hook for all relations is a very time consuming task
and the counter and total count allows easy tracking of a progress of
this operation.

Change-Id: Ia21bf77c18464a3d77af486a56694bcb5d8ab89f

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: Ia61dfb629036448f16edf44e3240c362157ffb74

commit_message:
Match testing matrix to supported backends

The OpenStack Charms project only supports the manila-ganesha
backend for shared filesystems, so testing charm-manila back
to it's introduction in Stein with the manila-generic
backend just to ensure that the manila APIs are working is
both a waste of testing resources as well as asserting a
support level that isn't matched by other systems.

Recent changes in the tests seem to expose an issue in the
manila-generic backend, as deployed by the charms, where
the share isn't being correctly created or something, where
the newer tests fail to actually access the share
concurrently from two guests.

Also synced release-tools in order to fix the build.

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/623
Closes-Bug: #1935022
Change-Id: Id6a0b40cba7bd46f476409a5a7cfdabb50f30839
Co-authored-by: Aurelien Lourot <aurelien.lourot@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add Juju storage support

Add support for juju storage. The functional tests should probably
move over to using juju storage too but I'll propose that as a
follow patch to the pr can catch any regression in the existing
functional tests.

Change-Id: I4c70a40e9bc0fe59eeec5165102d43ecad8e86df

commit_message:
Add check to ensure that ports are working

Change-Id: I0af8faaa95d47aecd3d061ea67f5410bfc6be20a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-manila refs/changes/06/709606/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import itertools import jsonimport tenacity@tenacity.retry(wait=tenacity.wait_exponential(multiplier=10, max=300), reraise=True, stop=tenacity.stop_after_attempt(3)) def _check_if_server_works_on_port(port): curl_cmd = ['curl', "localhost:{}".format(port)] try: output = subprocess.check_output(curl_cmd).decode('utf-8') except subprocess.CalledProcessError: return False try: res = json.loads(output) except json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: return False return True def custom_assess_status_last_check(self): """Verify that the configured API port is open and the service is up. This checks that the API is returning valid JSON from it's configured port to ensure that the service is actually available before setting the charm to active. :returns (status: string, message: string): the status, and message if there is a problem. Or (None, None) if there are no issues. """ ports = list(itertools.chain.from_iterable( [list(app.values()) for app in self.api_ports.values()])) results = [_check_if_server_works_on_port(port) for port in ports] matched = [p for p, opened in zip(ports, results) if opened == False] if matched: return ('blocked', 'Some ports are bound but not ready: {}' .format(' '.join(matched))) return None, None

commit_message:
ensure that cell properties are updated bedore to start db migration

In order to fix bug/1835037 the database URLs of each cells has to be
well updated that to include any change related to the driver.

Closes-Bug: #1835037
Change-Id: I693793d000cd7176b25f452c7b79b214e23b1b94
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

added_lines: # We force update of cell databases prior to execute the # online_data_migration. update_cell_database(["cell0", "cell1"])

commit_message:
Add support for cinder volume encryption r->t

Add support for volume encryption in bionic rocky to bionic train.
After train encryption works without any charm changes. Also add
testing of creating and encrypted volume in bionic rocky onwards.

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/662
Change-Id: I13be9899731e777d95351e00d0cc818f4d442251

commit_message:
Explicitly enable msgr2 for Nautilus and later

Closes-Bug: #1840701
Depends-On: Ib90cd03b16f2062fa6c6a43d242d51306ae8ca95
Change-Id: I08ad307a7226977d2afc93ca9537d1d1cfeb0c29
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/07/821707/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(jmcvaughn): # Nautilus and later binaries use msgr2 by default, but existing # clusters that have been upgraded from pre-Nautilus will not # automatically have msgr2 enabled. Without this, Ceph will show # a warning only (with no impact to operations), but newly added units # will not be able to join the cluster. Therefore, we ensure it is # enabled on upgrade for all versions including and after Nautilus # (to cater for previous charm versions that will not have done this). nautilus_or_later = cmp_pkgrevno('ceph-common', '14.0.0') >= 0 if nautilus_or_later: wait_for_all_monitors_to_upgrade(new_version=new_version, upgrade_key=upgrade_key) enable_msgr2()def enable_msgr2(): """ Enables msgr2 :raises: subprocess.CalledProcessError if the command fails """ cmd = ['ceph', 'mon', 'enable-msgr2'] subprocess.check_call(cmd)

commit_message:
Enable qemu remote-display-port-min configuration

Add the remote-display-port-min configuration paramter to config.yaml,
defaults to an unset value to preserve compatibilty with previous
charm versions. This setting allows to modify the initial qemu
vnc port 5900 and helps to prevent Intel NUC AMT vnc port overlaps.

Change-Id: I1aa7f7bf35972f884921f77e92ecb913c323d02a
Closes-Bug: #1844786

commit_message:
Updated test bundles to add second device

In functional testing of the set-weight action, it was found that
changes to ring devices is not triggering rebalance because there
are no changes to the partition placement.  Adding a second device to
the swift-storage units will change the partitions assigned to the disks
and allow for the rebalance and sync of rings to be validated during
functional testing.

Change-Id: I3f72da96edd97a479e0600f35d450fdf8aa077ae
Related-Bug: #1882250
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/328

commit_message:
Mask corosync service

In addition to removing the state left by the corosync
package, mask the service so that upgrades and updates
can process successfully.

This change also pins cffi for python<3.6, syncs pip updates
from release-tools, and updates the test's unit tests to the
new Yoga versions, dropping python3.5 from the upstream unit tests.

Closes-Bug: #1942343
Change-Id: Id803ed37729b53a14f20ffcf3cfa4df735c286e7

commit_message:
Implement NFS Support for Charmed Ceph

NFS support will be provided by a new principal charm that will provide
CephFS shares over NFS via the Ganesha package.

Change-Id: I621b697dfa023e97eab8a9c0113f87b439906db5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-specs refs/changes/06/819806/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2021 Canonical Limited. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: "None". For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ================ CephFS Over NFS ================ A charm should be created to provide access to CephFS via NFS. Problem Description =================== A detailed description of the problem.There is currently no user-friendly way to consume Ceph’s filesystems via NFS without using OpenStack. A charm should be created that provides NFS gateways via relations and charm action. Proposed Change =============== A charm will be created that uses Ganesha to provide CephFS shares as NFS shares. These shares will be created on-demand via an NFS relation or an action. Relations will be implemented consuming Ceph and providing NFS shares. Additionally, actions will be created that support managing NFS shares. Alternatives ------------ This is an optional section, where it does apply we'd just like a demonstration that some thought has been put into why the proposed approach is the best one. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: chrismacnaughton Can optionally list additional ids if they intend on doing substantial implementation work on this blueprint. Gerrit Topic ------------ Use Gerrit topic "ceph-nfs" for all patches related to this spec. .. code-block:: bash git-review -t ceph-nfs Work Items ---------- * Implement a new operator framework charm, ceph-nfs * Add actions to manage NFS shares * write unit tests * write functional tests using the zaza test framework (a functional test should include deploying ceph-mon with ceph-nfs added) * Verify NFS shares via action * Verify NFS shares via relation * Add a relation to a loadbalancer service which will provide a HA vip for accessing the shares. Timeline -------- The goal is to implement this change in the OpenStack Charms 22.04 release. Repositories ------------ During initial development the code will be managed here: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/charm-ceph-nfs When ready the charm will be managed via OpenDev gerrit. https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-nfs Documentation ------------- The charm should contain documented options: * Create charm options * Create charm actions * Create charm relations * Create charm README * Update of the official charm deployment guide: [0] [0]: https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/ Security -------- This charm provides storage over a network so should implement IP based access control rules. Testing ------- Code changes will be covered by unit tests. Functional tests would require ceph OSD hardware or software emulation. This is possible through Ceph cluster deployment. Dependencies ============ - This charm will support OpenStack Ussuri (Ceph Octopus) and Ubuntu 20.04 Focal as its baseline - A new project will need to be created based on the OpenStack Project `Creator's Guide <https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/creators.html>`

commit_message:
Explicit instruction to run `configure-resources`

Some config options require running the `configure-resources` action. Be
clear on the point in config.yaml.

Closes-Bug: #1937263
Change-Id: I0e7478e3c67fa629db763f3fd71148abe5f5a25a

deleted_lines: this key must be visible to the project used by Octavia. create a new one.

commit_message:
Add ceph status output to juju status

When the ceph cluster is unhealthy, we can
and should add the message from ceph to the
juju status output

Change-Id: I8a3b458c03e9f81ae883df632d42b6c997cf8b7b
Closes-Bug: #1796430

commit_message:
Stop setting default capabilities in get_named_key.

When get_named_key is called on a keyring that
has customised capabilities, it overwrites the
capabilities to the default capabilities.

Depends-On: I777650ae2194609a95e5cfb101e343824b3d0a34
Change-Id: I2930b32943fb75778cf3b56bb7f1d2a9f9c7c454
(cherry picked from commit 04a9c98dfaa760ff6b469ef448275f7e9796c8e3)

commit_message:
Update to classic charms to build using charmcraft in CI

This update is to ensure that the Zuul Canonical CI builds the charm
before functional tests and ensure that that artifact is used for the
functional tests.  This is to try to ensure that the charm that gets
landed to the charmhub is the same charm that was tested with.

This isn't a straight cherry-pick as it eneds to enable the Wallaby
CI jobs as well.

(cherry-picked from commit a7e6225b2b70e9bf09c54b3d1f9b3d2fa53eb4b4)

Change-Id: I57dcc28b826f6434e98b99216cef92ed9126ce85

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ops-openstack refs/changes/27/832227/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, relations, charm_instance, contexts=None, options_instance=None): :param contexts: List of contexts if contexts is None: contexts = () self._contexts = set() for context in contexts: self.add_context(context) Iterate over the relations and contexts presented to the charm. for ref in self._relations.union(self._contexts): yield ref, getattr(self, ref) def add_context(self, context): """Add the context to this adapters instance. :param relation: a RAW context """ setattr(self, context.name, context) self._contexts.add(context.name)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, relations, charm_instance, options_instance=None): Iterate over the relations presented to the charm. for relation in self._relations: yield relation, getattr(self, relation)

commit_message:
Option to enable network-segment-range support

To let operators add an additional and optional service plugin into the
deployment configuration as "network_segment_range".
https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-network-segment-ranges.html

Closes-Bug: #1965229
Change-Id: Id0ac7c397874ad2c51935e8c0eab64f1ef4f6fd3
(cherry picked from commit c411b90d2d14e7ad7678e0ce0b81ac82fdaffa3a)

commit_message:
insert local modules to sys.path beginning instead of appending to end

local module paths should be inserted into beginning of sys.path, so they can be used first by python interpreter.
Otherwise when a global copy exists, local copy will be ignored, and cause unexpected error.

For example, `charmhelpers` error in this bug:
LP: #1919949

Code in this patch is following existing pattern[0].
paths are inserted at 1 instead 0, because 0 is normally current dir, which should have highest priority.

[0]: https://github.com/openstack/charm-nova-compute/blob/433796779e4f31320e6c57527f421d4e9aaacedc/actions/pause_resume.py#L20

Closes-Bug: #1919949
Change-Id: Idd61274b7abd0226b625cf334ab0b7f125146aec
Signed-off-by: Joe Guo <joe.guo@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add spec for Cinder Infinidat backend

Change-Id: I3a3662a1aef352685fb8a16d55dcb504d7030e1f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-specs refs/changes/70/838670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2022 Canonical Ltd. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Cinder subordinate charm cinder-infinidat ========================================= Problem Description =================== Cinder has a great number of drivers for different backends. Almost all currently available commercial storage arrays and many other software only solutions have a driver available, if not already in the upstream cinder project, as an installable package that enables cinder with the extra driver. Because of how many possibilities exist, a model was developed where a separate subordinate charm will be deployed to take care of the specifics of the driver and pass configuration to the main cinder charm over a relation so that cinder can write to its own configuration file. Proposed Change =============== Instead of changing the cinder charm, this proposal aims to create a separate subordinate charm specific for the infinidat driver. This cinder installation would enable access to Infinidat devices. The following points are of considerable importance for the development of this subordinate charm: * The new implementation should not conflict with current implementation. Both should co-exist, even in the same deployment if possible. * The new charm should implement all features currently existing in the cinder charm, regarding the infinidat functionality. Note that because the Infinidat driver is part of the cinder-common package, no additional packages need to be installed for this charm to work. This charm would be supported in the Ussuri release of Openstack and newer. Configuration values: .. code-block:: none chap-password type: string Description: Password for CHAP authentication. chap-username type: string Description: Username for CHAP authentication. extra_packages type: string Description: Space separated list of extra deb packages to install. infinibox-ip type: string Description: Management VIP address of the Infinibox. infinibox-login type: string Description: The username for management api on the Infinibox. infinibox-password type: string Description: The password for management api on the Infinibox. install_keys type: string Description: List of signing keys for install_sources package sources, per charmhelpers standard format (a yaml list of strings encoded as a string). The keys should be the full ASCII armoured GPG public keys. While GPG key ids are also supported and looked up on a keyserver, operators should be aware that this mechanism is insecure. null can be used if a standard package signing key is used that will already be installed on the machine, and for PPA sources where the package signing key is securely retrieved from Launchpad. install_sources type: string Description: List of extra apt sources, per charm-helpers standard format (a yaml list of strings encoded as a string). Each source may be either a line that can be added directly to sources.list(5), or in the form ppa:<user>/<ppa-name> for adding Personal Package Archives, or a distribution component to enable. iscsi-netspaces type: string Description: Comma seperated list of iSCSI netspaces to use. package_status type: string Default: install Description: The status of service-affecting packages will be set to this value in the dpkg database. Valid values are "install" and "hold". pool-name type: string Description: Storage pool to use on the Infinibox. protocol type: string Default: iscsi Description: SAN protocol to use. Choose between iscsi or fc. thin-provision type: boolean Default: True Description: Choose whether to allocate thin provisioned volumes. use-chap type: boolean Description: Choose whether to use CHAP authentication for iSCSI. use-compression type: boolean Default: True Description: Choose whether to use compression on volumes. volume-backend-name type: string Description: Volume backend service name to define in Cinder. Juju 2.9 or newer is required. Alternatives ------------ At the time of this writing, there exist no alternatives. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zeeshan Ali Shah <zeeshan.alishah@canonical.com> - LP ID: babal1nux Secondary assignee: tbd <tbd@canonical.com> - LP ID: tbd Gerrit Topic ------------ Use Gerrit topic "charm-cinder-infinidat" for all patches related to this spec. .. code-block:: bash git-review -t charm-cinder-infinidat Work Items ---------- The charm, as listed above. Plus, both unit and functional tests will be written. Repositories ------------ Presently, the following repository hosts the charm code: https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-cinder-infinidat Documentation ------------- Once this charm is completed, charm-guide will be updated to reference it. Security -------- No security aspect is going to change in relation to the current solution. Testing ------- Code changes will be covered by both unit and functional tests. Functional tests would require infinidat storage hardware. Dependencies ============ No dependencies in addition to the ones that exist in the current solution.

commit_message:
Add configuration option for entityID.

Sets the entityID in the service provider metadata file.
If not provided, entityID is autogenerated.

commit_message:
Update python testing as per zed cycle testing runtime

In Zed cycle, we have dropped the python 3.6/3.7[1] testing
and its support. Moving the py36 job to py38 based as well as
updating the python classifier also to reflect the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Change-Id: I66f32ce3ae4a0aa032fc8918d83bef30a588d18b

commit_message:
Re-render configuration files when new certificates are presented.

When certificates presented by ovn-chassis over the ovsdb-subordinate
relation change the configuration files need to be rendered again to
reflect the possible change of certificates, the most common scenario
where this is needed is when the certificates are rotate with the
"reissue-certificates" action from Vault charm.

Closes-Bug: #1952279
Change-Id: If7d4783bb8ee8583ec5ce8b9f13da9bcf4c5952f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-octavia refs/changes/38/819438/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @reactive.when('endpoint.ovsdb-subordinate.changed.chassis-certificates') reactive.clear_flag( 'endpoint.ovsdb-subordinate.changed.chassis-certificates')

commit_message:
Remove departed mon from map

When a unit departs, we need to actually remove the mon so that
further commands aren't directed at it. Thus, it is necessary to
tell ceph that a particular mon should be removed.

Change-Id: I78953cea629c1a31ce842c85fb9f601f85043cc1
Closes-Bug: #1833252
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/650
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/23/812623/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'is_leader') @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'hook_name') @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'departing_unit') @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'relation_ids') @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'relation_get') @patch.object(ceph_hooks, 'mon_remove') def test_mon_departure(self, mon_remove, relation_get, relation_ids, departing_unit, hook_name, is_leader): is_leader.return_value = True hook_name.return_value = 'mon-relation-departed' departing_unit.return_value = 'some-unit' relation_ids.return_value = ['relid1'] relation_get.return_value = '127.0.0.1' ceph_hooks.handle_mon_departure() mon_remove.assert_called_with(relation_get.return_value) relation_get.return_value = None mon_remove.reset_mock() ceph_hooks.handle_mon_departure() mon_remove.assert_not_called()

added_lines: import math import multiprocessing "libpython2.7", "pigz"] gzcmd = ["/usr/bin/pigz", "--processes", math.ceil(multiprocessing.cpu_count()/2), _filename]

subject: Add action mark-seeded
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-16 19:06:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-percona-cluster/commit/65407028cdd9f31c21d4c8345af07dce4ac73325', 'message': "Add action mark-seeded

The charm uses a file named 'seeded' to determine if the cluster is ready
to perform operations by the charm hooks (e.g. create a database on
shared-db-relation-changed), there could be a case where an operator needs
to manipulate the cluster outside the charm's context and this action would
allow them to mark the unit as ready to process requests after that said
manipulation.

Change-Id: I13d2ff75c656a952629f6ba40a5c2d24247a7682
Closes-Bug: #1867456

commit_message:
Add action mark-seeded

The charm uses a file named 'seeded' to determine if the cluster is ready
to perform operations by the charm hooks (e.g. create a database on
shared-db-relation-changed), there could be a case where an operator needs
to manipulate the cluster outside the charm's context and this action would
allow them to mark the unit as ready to process requests after that said
manipulation.

Change-Id: I13d2ff75c656a952629f6ba40a5c2d24247a7682
Closes-Bug: #1867456
Func-Test-Pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/204

commit_message:
Fix updating a non-HTTP(S) Health Monitor

Prevent octavia-dashboard from sending parameters that trigger a
InvalidOption exception when updating a non-HTTP/non-HTTPS health
monitor.

Story 2008803
Task 42223

Change-Id: Ie669829b149001f77f7475216b86a33d96cb5ff5

commit_message:
Update the bundles to use the stable track, edge risk for yoga

The bundles for the yoga channel currently point to "latest/edge"
channel for all the charms.  This update points the charms to the
appropriate channel for the charm being used, either from ceph,
openstack, ovn or the misc tracks.

Change-Id: Ia957590d615d031c8c35382a0327bce11f78bd94

commit_message:
Review charm upgrades

Comprehensive review of the upgrade-charms page.

In particular, cover channel type charms. Link to
the Xena guide for legacy type charm coverage.

This PR will be backported to the Yoga guide.

added_lines: The command to use for performing a charm upgrade is :command:`juju upgrade-charm`. For extra guidance see `Upgrading applications`_ in the Juju documentation.There is no special order in which the charms are upgraded, but do ensure that each charm's upgrade is successful before proceeding to the next. time). Although charm upgrade order is irrelevant, for consistency purposes, the order shown on this page is the order used for :ref:`OpenStack upgrades <openstack_upgrade_order>`, which, in turn, is the order used by internal testing.#. all principal charmsThe precise order for the group of principal charms is shown in the below.. list-table:: Principal charmsall the principal charms have been processed all the subordinate charms canis running Stein. The keystone **charm** however shows a revision number ofSo to upgrade the keystone charm (to the most recent promulgated version in the Charm Store):latest stable revision. This means that intervening revisions can be conveniently skipped. Use the ``--revision`` option to specify a target revision. commit_message:
Update the bundles to use the stable track, edge risk for yoga

The bundles for the yoga channel currently point to "latest/edge"
channel for all the charms.  This update points the charms to the
appropriate channel for the charm being used, either from ceph,
openstack, ovn or the misc tracks.

Change-Id: I03e36b25dd2a68d6294f1613ca9064478e8295c8

commit_message:
Set recoveryMethod from clone to auto

Forcing a full snapshot with clone option may cause addInstance
to fail because there is an already stablished group replication.

Interactive mode should be disabled since charm is handling
this call.

Closes-Bug: #1912688
Change-Id: I8426cd49c8201b3f116d8cacb353453cc6fba588
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-mysql-innodb-cluster refs/changes/82/771882/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
nclu-switch: Fix order in template

Currently description is applied first to the interface, but if it's a
virtual one - it won't exist before running the configuration commands.

Story: 2010279
Task: 46232

Change-Id: I40212b40a4d391272f4063f42e8a7043b3d58fd7
(cherry picked from commit cfb5c004eafd7df7e0c5e94b7697811e174301ff)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/93/856493/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes an issue with nclu-switch command ordering, when description was applied first to a non-existent (virtual) interface. See `story 2010279 <https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2010279>`__ for details.

commit_message:
Add vm.watermark_scale_factor tuning

Depends: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/609
Implements: spec memory-fragmentation-tuning
Change-Id: I0195d5f65f36442abf1355dd5150d48a37184e97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-swift-storage refs/changes/99/792899/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yaml ERROR,from charmhelpers.contrib.sysctl.watermark_scale_factor import ( calculate_watermark_scale_factor, ) sysctl_settings = config('sysctl') try: sysctl_dict_parsed = yaml.safe_load(sysctl_settings) except yaml.YAMLError: log("Error parsing YAML sysctl_dict: {}".format(sysctl_settings), level=ERROR) if (config('tune-watermark-scale-factor') is True and "vm.watermark_scale_factor" not in sysctl_dict_parsed): try: wmark = calculate_watermark_scale_factor() sysctl_dict_parsed["vm.watermark_scale_factor"] = wmark except Exception: pass if sysctl_dict_parsed: create_sysctl(sysctl_dict_parsed, '/etc/sysctl.d/50-swift-storage-charm.conf')

commit_message:
zuul: fix the grenade job to actually test barbican

Add the required services and run a few barbican-specific tests
to validate the upgrade.

The grenade plugin contains a few settings which don't need to be
set anymore explicitly and they are not in the job configuration
(as devstack/upgrade/settings is not used anymore):
- all the image-related variables don't need to be overridden anymore,
  the default one from devstack should be used
- Image API v1 has been disabled since tempest 20.0

The job can be switched to voting again.

Change-Id: Id0682aea57d4d1fc49334f2dd11ef9a0ffb355fb

commit_message:
Fix Non-OpenStack dynamic pollster credentials handling

There was a problem with the barbican credentials processing for
Non-OpenStack dynamic pollster. The credentials variables would be
retrieved as a byte string, which would break the processing.
Therefore, we needed to introduce a method to check if the credentials
are a String object. if they are not, we convert them to String.

Change-Id: I2084061eb8f543d4c557963599732e35cfa22996

commit_message:
Support use of etcd as a storage backend for Vault

This change adds an option for the charm user to specify etcd as the
storage backend for Vault. This is in addition to the option of using
it as the HA storage which already exists prior to this change.

The existing functional test as "test_consistent_read_write" will check
that a written data can be read from all vault units in HA scenarios as
the same way as other storage backends already availalbe such as MySQL
and PostgreSQL.

Co-Authored-By: Mark S. Maglana <mark.maglana@canonical.com>
Closes-Bug: 1883242
Change-Id: I2ec6285a44bb5e1914839bd33dc1e778ae4a85fd

commit_message:
Add Kinetic and Zed support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to zed
* align testing with zed
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases
* add bindep.txt for py310
* sync tox.ini and requirements.txt for ruamel
* use charmcraft_channel 2.0/stable
* drop reactive plugin overrides
* move interface/layer env vars to charmcraft.yaml

Change-Id: I0776bad299d133b61dc8e2941c40eeb572f5af78

commit_message:
Add Kinetic and Zed support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to zed
* align testing with zed
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases
* add bindep.txt for py310
* sync tox.ini and requirements.txt for ruamel
* use charmcraft_channel 2.0/stable
* drop reactive plugin overrides
* move interface/layer env vars to charmcraft.yaml

Change-Id: I2c98ab0f82aa6d6d0a43365cee04d6da34a39ce4

added_lines: series: kinetic series: focal # Note that holding memcached at focal as it's not available at kinetic yet. series: focal
deleted_lines: series: impish series: bionic # holding charm at bionic as it isn't available for focal+ yet series: bionic series: focal

commit_message:
Use venv instead of virtualenv

virtualenv is not a part of the core python installation, but
venv is. Let's use it to be slimmer and avoid issues with
virtualenv installation.

At the same time, remove some existing hacks around selinux,
systemd, PyYAML and libvirt.

Change-Id: Icd60aca084323cede944ee261d2cf5941b320e4b

commit_message:
Fix misuse of assert statements

Replace 'called_once_with' with 'assert_called_once_with'.
Replace 'called_once' with 'assert_called_once_with'.

Change-Id: I1d3c444c3e01b862a1a2571cf13d054dfd2fb463
Closes-Bug: 1989267
Signed-off-by: Takashi Natsume <takanattie@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add Kinetic and Zed support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to zed
* align testing with zed
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases
* add bindep.txt for py310
* sync tox.ini and requirements.txt for ruamel
* use charmcraft_channel 2.0/stable
* drop reactive plugin overrides
* move interface/layer env vars to charmcraft.yaml

Change-Id: I506c53b4956024066bc769665525cb022438a0ae

commit_message:
Add Kinetic and Zed support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to zed
* align testing with zed
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases
* add bindep.txt for py310
* sync tox.ini and requirements.txt for ruamel
* use charmcraft_channel 2.0/stable
* drop reactive plugin overrides
* move interface/layer env vars to charmcraft.yaml

Change-Id: I3cc0af8443ecf62589c88d4e924cb633c419e87f

commit_message:
Add Kinetic and Zed support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to zed
* align testing with zed
* add new zed bundles
* add zed bundles to tests.yaml
* add zed tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases
* add bindep.txt for py310
* sync tox.ini and requirements.txt for ruamel
* use charmcraft_channel 2.0/stable
* drop reactive plugin overrides
* move interface/layer env vars to charmcraft.yaml
* enable qos service plugin for neutron-api to ensure
  migrate-ovn-db action is successful

Change-Id: I6f94ff3e557413b6096493f839c0a5f217c017d3
Closes-Bug: #1988089

subject: Build separately for each supported series and use binary builds
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-08-10 14:51:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-octavia-diskimage-retrofit/commit/94d6d1062b1126f90dbc430e50fc70fc21e190c7', 'message': 'wip: allow charm to work on Jammy

The cryptography pin does not work well with jammy as the compiled
artifact is not compatible with OpenSSL 3.0.

Given we already compile C dependencies on the hosts, the reasoing
of not using the most recent version of cryptography because it
depends on a rust compiler is a bit weird.

Also, it may be that we need a different version of the charm for
Focal and Jammy, which does not sitt well with the current build
strategy of renaming *.charm to charm-name.charm, effectively
overwriting the multiple artifacts that charmcraft provides when
specifying multiple bases in charmcraft.yaml.

Experiment a bit with how to resolve these issues, relevant bugs:
https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zosci-config/issues/222
https://github.com/openstack-charmers/release-tools/issues/249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-octavia-diskimage-retrofit/+bug/1981334

Change-Id: I8c924038ee1c5ff258c41a44ad14ebc86a107b1b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-09-06 16:38:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-octavia-diskimage-retrofit/commit/9ccc6e06d5fb923c7e5cc8ac92fcd5526908d80a', 'message': 'WIP: Build separately for each supported series

__NOTE__: This review contains in-flight layer code and makes
use of wip changes to charm-tools.  These need to merge and
release before we can merge this patch set.

Charms for OpenStack Yoga supports both Ubuntu Focal and Jammy
which means Python 3.8 and Python 3.10.  Managing dependencies
across those two versions is non-trivial and we need to build
the charm on the series the charm is supposed to support.

The cryptography pin does not work well with jammy as the compiled
artifact is not compatible with OpenSSL 3.0.

Given we already compile C dependencies on the hosts, the
reasoning of not using the most recent version of cryptography
because it depends on a rust compiler is a bit weird.

Update charm to consume the 1.0/stable track for the snap.

Bundles:
- Drop the renaming of the charm artifact and reference the
  series specific charm artifact in the bundles instead.
- Fix gss mirror list, jammy retrofit-series and use 8.0/stable
  for MySQL.

Closes-Bug: #1981334
Change-Id: I8c924038ee1c5ff258c41a44ad14ebc86a107b1b

Update charm to consume the 1.0/stable track for the snap.

Bundles:

  for MySQL.

Closes-Bug: #1981334
Closes-Bug: #1970653
